name: Dungeon adventure

globals.miniondescription: Servants of evil have gathered here.
globals.guardiandescription: A suspicious-looking guardian blocks the way.
globals.monsterdescription: A monster seems to have a scent of something.
globals.beastdescription: An unnaturally deformed beast is approaching.
globals.traitoraction: seems to be listening to you
globals.traitordescription: A scholar seems to take an interest to you.
globals.shapeshifterdescription: The skinghanger is lost in thoughts.
globals.tempteraction: is casting a long, ponderous look at you
globals.tempterdescription: A beautiful enchantress smiles by herself.
globals.rivaldescription: A knight looks at you disapprovingly.
globals.inhabitantdescription: Gnomes in conical hats have gathered together.
globals.animaldescription: A rat-like shape scurries in the shadows.
globals.captivedescription: A captive tries in vain to gain freedom.
globals.heralddescription: A scared child wanders here aimlessly.
globals.mentordescription: A sage is studying his environs.
globals.allyaction: tries to make as little noise as possible
globals.allydescription: A group of minions seems to be hiding from their kin.
globals.roomdescription: This room appears to be long since abandoned.
globals.roomevent: Strange noises can be heard from ahead.
globals.groundfeature: a dried up patch of blood
globals.dangeraction: seems to be all too near
globals.dangerdescription: Here a nest of snakes writhes feverishly!
globals.trialdescription: A heavy looking portcullis blocks the way.
globals.hindranceaction: slowly sucks in anyone stepping into it
globals.hindrancedescription: A pool of quagmire covers the entire floor here.
globals.setbackaction: makes part of the area inaccessible
globals.setbackdescription: A collapsed ceiling blocks a part of the area here.
globals.trapdescription: A scythe has been fastened high in the ceiling.

structure: Produces dungeon descriptions based on the 'Five Room Dungeon' concept and Hollywood scriptwriting formulas.
note: Forked from the Five_room_dungeon generator on 2018-01-04.
to do: More external table calls to add variety.
see: dungeon_entrance, dungeon_corridor, dungeon_room, dungeon_vault, Five_room_dungeon, hook_line_and_sinker_adventure
authors: ELF Vesala, based on the 'Five Room Dungeon' formula, the Hero's Journey and scriptwriting methodology.
sources: Dream Park: The Roleplaying Game, Five_room_dungeon, RolePlayingTips.com

tables.name: init
tables.explanation: Initializing the dungeon parameters.

tables.name: result
tables.explanation: Verbosity of the resultPattern output.

tables.name: summary
tables.explanation: Brief resultPattern output.

tables.name: detail
tables.explanation: Detailed resultPattern output variations.

tables.name: alternative
tables.explanation: Alternative structures.

tables.name: adventure description
tables.explanation: The adventure described from start to finish.
entries: {adventure title} {motif note} {villain note} {goal note} {macguffin note} {treasure note} {complication note} {difficulty note} {introduction} {adventure structure} {duration note}

tables.name: five room dungeon
tables.explanation: This is an older model is based more strictly on the 'Five Room Dungeon' formula.

tables.name: adventure title
tables.explanation: The adventure name as a subheading.

tables.name: adventure name
tables.explanation: Variations for the name of the adventure based on set variables.
entries: In search of the {global:treasure} of the {lib:villain#adjective} {global:villain}

tables.name: motif note
tables.explanation: Description of the general theme of the adventure.

tables.name: difficulty note
tables.explanation: A paragraph describing the difficulty of the adventure.

tables.name: villain note
tables.explanation: Introductory words about the villain.

tables.name: goal note
tables.explanation: Introductory words about the goal and target.

tables.name: macguffin note
tables.explanation: Description of the macguffin of the adventure.
entries: {global:para}{global:startbold}Macguffin:{global:endbold} The adventure starts when the {lib:synonym#troupe} finds out about a {lib:macguffin#detail}.

tables.name: treasure note
tables.explanation: Description of the treasure of the adventure.
entries: {global:para}{global:startbold}Treasure:{global:endbold} Some {lib:treasure#adjective} {lib:treasure} is said to be hidden in the dungeon - but little do they know that it is {lib:treasure#complication}...

tables.name: complication note
tables.explanation: An optional complication for the adventure.

tables.name: introduction
tables.explanation: How the adventurers start the adventure.
entries: {global:para}Here the {lib:synonym#troupe} {encountering} a {lib:villain#adjective} {global:villain} and a band of {global:minions}. Will the {lib:synonym#troupe} be able to {global:goal} {global:target}?

tables.name: encountering
tables.explanation: Introductory words about adventurers facing the villain.

tables.name: duration note
tables.explanation: A paragraph about the estimated duration of the adventure, based on the number of scenes.
entries: {global:para}[The duration of the {lib:synonym#adventure} is estimated to be roughly {global:duration} minutes.]

tables.name: footnote
tables.explanation: A potential footnote (usually empty).

tables.name: goal
tables.explanation: The aim of the adventure.

tables.name: room 1
tables.explanation: There needs to be a reason why your dungeon hasn't been plundered before or why the PCs are the heroes for the job. A guardian or challenge at the entrance is a good justification why the location remains intact. Also, a guardian sets up early action to capture player interest and energize a session.

tables.name: entrance
tables.explanation: Entrance to the dungeon. Add mood and theme!
entries: The entrance is hidden by an overcrop of rock.
The entrance requires a {lib:key} that is {key location}.
The entrance is guarded by {lib:actant#guardian} that keeps intruders out.
A {lib:actant#guardian} is not indigenous to the dungeon but has made its lair by the entrance.
A hazard prevents entering and requires special skills and equipment to bypass: {lib:hazard#detail}

tables.name: room 2
tables.explanation: The PCs are victorious over the challenge of the first room and are now presented with a trial that cannot be solved with steel. This keeps problem solvers in your group happy and breaks the action up for good pacing. Make Room Two a puzzle, skill-based, or roleplaying encounter, if possible. Room Two should shine the limelight on different PCs than Room One, change gameplay up, and offer variety between the challenge at the entrance and the challenge at the end. Note, if Room One was this type of encounter, then feel free to make Room Two combat-oriented. Room Two should allow for multiple solutions to prevent the game from stalling. Add clues to room 1!

tables.name: puzzle
tables.explanation: A trial that cannot be solved with steel.
entries: A dirt floor crawls with poisonous snakes that will slither out of the way to avoid open flame. (A few might follow at a distance and strike later on.)

tables.name: information gathering
entries: All the visible exits turn out to be blocked, and there is no obvious way to proceed. The correct approach must be figured out via clues.

tables.name: magic puzzle
entries: The floor is covered from wall to wall with chessboard tiles. Stepping on wrong squares triggers a {lib:trap}.

tables.name: roleplaying challenge
entries: A guardian spirit blocks access to the rest of the complex and must be befriended, not fought.
A {global:minion} standing on guard can be bluffed or coerced without raising the alarm.
The adventurers must convince a {global:minion} to let them in.

tables.name: room 3
tables.explanation: The purpose of this room is to build tension. Do this using a trick, trap, or setback. For example, after defeating a tough monster, and players think they've finally found the treasure and achieved their goal, they learn they've been tricked and the room is a false crypt. Depending on your game system, use this room to cater to any player or character types not yet served by the first two areas. Alternatively, give your group a double-dose of gameplay that they enjoy the most, such as more combat or roleplaying. Another potential payoff for Room Three is to weaken the PCs as build-up to a dramatic struggle in Room Four. It might contain a tough combat encounter, take down a key defense, exhaust an important resource, or make the party susceptible to a certain type of attack. For example, if Room Four contains a mummy whose secret weakness is fire, then make Room Three a troll lair (or another creature susceptible to fire) so the PCs might be tempted to burn off a lot of their fire magic, oil, and other flammable resources. This would turn a plain old troll battle into a gotcha once the PCs hit Room Four and realize the are out of fire resources. Don't forget to dress Room Three up with your theme elements!

tables.name: trick room
entries: Here the adventurers can rescue a {global:captivegroup}. However, the {global:captives} {lib:complication#captive}.

tables.name: trapped room
entries: There is a {global:trap} in the room: {lib:trap#detail}.

tables.name: setback room
entries: A collapsed structure blocks part of the {lib:synonym#room}. The debris is dangerous and blocks {blocked area}.
{one way exit} leading back to room 1.

tables.name: complication room
entries: The {artifact} required to defeat the {global:villain}, but it is {lib:complication#item}. Clues reveal that a solution lies ahead.
Believing the object of the quest now lays within easy reach, a  companion turns traitor and betrays the {lib:synonym#troupe}.

tables.name: artifact
tables.explanation: Artifacts useful for solving the adventure.

tables.name: room 4
tables.explanation: This room is The Big Show. It's the final combat or conflict encounter of the dungeon. Use all the tactics you can summon to make this encounter memorable and entertaining. As always, generate interesting terrain that will impact the battle!

tables.name: climax
entries: The {global:villain} is here, ready to face the {lib:synonym#troupe}. Previous rooms have contained warning signals or an alarm, so the {global:villain} has had time to prepare.
The {global:villain} is here, and seems to be surprised by the arrival of the {lib:synonym#troupe}. The {global:villain} tries to settle things in an unusual way, through {unusual proposal}.
The {global:villain} is here and reveals the {global:treasure} to the {lib:synonym#troupe}, threatening to {reward threat}.
The {global:villain} is here, but has a weakness that the {lib:synonym#troupe} must figure out how to exploit.

tables.name: reward threat
entries: put it out of the reach of the {lib:synonym#troupe} so they'll never collect it

tables.name: big battle
entries: The {global:villain} is here and has unexpected {capabilities}.
The {global:villain} is here, but the {lib:synonym#room} is trapped. The {global:villain} {trap ability}.

tables.name: trap ability
entries: knows what to avoid in order to not trigger the traps
knows what areas to avoid in order to not trigger the traps
has the ability to set off the traps at opportune moments

tables.name: conflict
entries: A variety of skills and talents are required to successfully complete the encounter.

tables.name: roleplaying opportunity
entries: The {global:villain} needs to stall for time to {reason to stall}.
A victorious combat ends with the {global:villain} bleeding to death and a few short words can be exchanged.
There is a helpless {global:captivegroup} to roleplay with once the threat is dealt with.

tables.name: room 5
tables.explanation: Here's your opportunity to change the players' bragging to 'we came, we saw, we slipped on a banana peel.' Room Five doesn't always represent a complication or point of failure for the PCs, but it can. Room Five doesn't always need to be a physical location either - it can be a twist revealed in Room Four. Room Five is where your creativity can shine and is often what will make the dungeon different and memorable from the other crawls in your campaigns. In addition, if you haven't supplied the reward yet for conquering the dungeon, here is a good place to put the object of the quest, chests of loot, or the valuable information the PCs need to save the kingdom. As accounting tasks take over from recent, thrilling, combat tasks, this would also be a good time to make a campaign or world revelation, or a plot twist.

tables.name: reward
entries: A {lib:treasure#bonus} is discovered that leads to another adventure.

tables.name: surprise
entries: A monster is hiding in the treasure container: {lib:monster#detail}.
A trap that resurrects or renews the challenge from Room Four.

tables.name: revelation
entries: The location of the next adventure is uncovered, along with sufficient motivation to accept the quest.
The true identity of the {global:villain} is revealed.
New clues and information pertaining to a major plot arc are embedded in the treasure, {information hiding place}.
The {global:villain} is found to have a stronger, more fearsome master.
The grand scheme of the {global:villain} is discovered.
The source of an alien race's hostility towards others is uncovered, transforming them from villains to sympathetic characters in the story.
The true meaning of the prophecy or poem that lead the {lib:synonym#troupe} to the dungeon is finally understood, and it's not what the {lib:synonym#troupe} thought.

tables.name: information hiding place
entries: written on a slip of paper stuffed into a scroll tube
written using a cipher in the margins of a book

tables.name: plot twist
entries: A rival enters and tries to steal the reward while the {lib:synonym#troupe} is weakened after the big challenge of the previous room.
The object of the quest final reward isn't what it seems or has a complication. i.e. The kidnapped king doesn't want to return.
The quest was a trick. By killing the {global:villain} the {lib:synonym#troupe} has actually helped the {longterm villain}. The {global:villain} was actually {bad guy true form}.

tables.name: bad guy true form
entries: a good guy under a curse
a good guy placed into difficult circumstances

tables.name: adventure structure
tables.explanation: The path the adventure takes.

tables.name: duration
tables.explanation: The approximate duration of the game night.

tables.name: ca 90 minute adventure
tables.explanation: An adventure structure taking about 1.5 hours to play.

tables.name: ca 120 minute adventure
tables.explanation: An adventure structure taking about 2 hours to play.

tables.name: ca 150 minute adventure
tables.explanation: An adventure structure taking about 2.5 hours to play.

tables.name: ca 180 minute adventure
tables.explanation: An adventure structure taking about 3 hours to play.
entries: {lib:scene#action hook} {lib:scene#development scene} {lib:scene#action scene} {lib:scene#development scene} {lib:scene#action scene} {lib:scene#development finale} {lib:scene#resolution}
{lib:scene#development hook} {lib:scene#action scene} {lib:scene#development scene} {lib:scene#action scene} {lib:scene#development scene} {lib:scene#action finale} {lib:scene#resolution}

tables.name: ca 210 minute adventure
tables.explanation: An adventure structure taking about 3.5 hours to play.
entries: {lib:scene#action hook} {lib:scene#development scene} {lib:scene#action scene} {lib:scene#development scene} {lib:scene#action scene} {lib:scene#development scene} {lib:scene#action finale} {lib:scene#resolution}

{lib:scene#development hook} {lib:scene#action scene} {lib:scene#development scene} {lib:scene#action scene} {lib:scene#development scene} {lib:scene#action scene} {lib:scene#development finale} {lib:scene#resolution}

tables.name: ca 240 minute adventure
tables.explanation: An adventure structure taking about 4 hours to play.
entries: {lib:scene#action hook} {lib:scene#development scene} {lib:scene#action scene} {lib:scene#development scene} {lib:scene#action scene} {lib:scene#development scene} {lib:scene#action scene} {lib:scene#development finale} {lib:scene#resolution}

{lib:scene#development hook} {lib:scene#action scene} {lib:scene#development scene} {lib:scene#action scene} {lib:scene#development scene} {lib:scene#action scene} {lib:scene#development scene} {lib:scene#action finale} {lib:scene#resolution}

tables.name: HTML formatting
tables.explanation: Set variables for formatting the output as HTML

tables.name: CL formatting
tables.explanation: Set variables for formatting the output for Campaign Logger

tables.name: difficulty
tables.explanation: Difficulty levels by rarity.

tables.name: common
tables.explanation: Common difficulty levels.

tables.name: rare
tables.explanation: Rare difficulty levels.

export.difficultydescription: only the most experienced of adventurers

tables.name: minion
tables.explanation: The villain's minions.

tables.name: special
tables.explanation: Special tables.

tables.name: adjective
tables.explanation: Adjectives for the dungeon.

tables.name: key location
tables.explanation: Hiding place of the key.
entries: buried nearby (with still visible signs of digging)

tables.name: motif
tables.explanation: Theme of the dungeon concept.

export.motifdescription: An abandoned structure overrun by unclean infestations of vermin - and something even more dangerous.
A shrine of dark forces, featuring ghastly altars and worshippers of malevolent entities.
An underground structure guarded by vicious monsters and traps, brimming with treasure.
An ancient cataclysm toppled a forgotten city into a deep underground cavern.
Something has awakened the cadavers resting in an ancient catacomb.
Last remains of a long-dead civilization have entrenched themselves deep underground.
An age-old savage empire finally fell when it was overrun by a deluge. Its flooded remains now await explorers deep below ground.
Something horrific lives deep underground beneath the daylit world, and now it has crawled its way closer to the surface.
Magical energies emanating from deep underground have corrupted underground denizens into horrific beasts.
A gateway to nether realms has opened, vomiting out hellish denizens of the underworld to occupy their new abode.

tables.name: test
tables.explanation: Dumping the global variables.
entries: Motif: {global:motif}, difficulty: {global:difficulty}, goal: {global:goal}, artifact: {global:artifact}, danger: {global:danger}, treasure: {global:treasure}, villain: {global:villain}, minion: {global:minion}.
